questions.question_text_1: Which of the following is not a frontend framework?
question_texts: Which of the following is not a frontend framework?

questions.question_text_1: Consider the following statements and select the correct option:  Statement 1: In a database, an index can only be created on one column of a table.  Statement 2: Indexes cannot be created on columns which have duplicate values.
question_texts: Consider the following statements and select the correct option:  Statement 1: In a database, an index can only be created on one column of a table.  Statement 2: Indexes cannot be created on columns which have duplicate values.

options.option_text: Statement 1 is true & statement 2 is false
Statement 2 is true & statement 1 is false

questions.question_text_1: The lens of an HDD can read data on the rotating disk with the speed of 42,000 bits per second. The disk is designed such that 600 bits pass under the lens for every revolution of the disk, what should be the maximum speed of disk in RPM so that the lens does not miss any data?
question_texts: The lens of an HDD can read data on the rotating disk with the speed of 42,000 bits per second. The disk is designed such that 600 bits pass under the lens for every revolution of the disk, what should be the maximum speed of disk in RPM so that the lens does not miss any data?

questions.question_text_1: In an OpenAPI documentation, which field contains all the endpoints (routes) of the API?
question_texts: In an OpenAPI documentation, which field contains all the endpoints (routes) of the API?

options.option_text: One Book to one Author relationship
One Author to many Books relationship
Many Authors to one Book relationship
Many Books to many Author relationship

questions.question_text_1: Consider the following graph that represents the variation in bandwidth of a network for an entire day (24 hours). Three users were connected to the network at three different times of the day. What is the total data consumed in GigaBytes by all the users in 24 hrs?
questions.question_text_2: Consider the following graph that represents the variation in bandwidth of a network for an entire day (24 hours). Three users were connected to the network at three different times of the day. What is the total data consumed in GigaBytes by all the users in 24 hrs?
question_texts: Consider the following graph that represents the variation in bandwidth of a network for an entire day (24 hours). Three users were connected to the network at three different times of the day. What is the total data consumed in GigaBytes by all the users in 24 hrs?

Consider the following graph that represents the variation in bandwidth of a network for an entire day (24 hours). Three users were connected to the network at three different times of the day. What is the total data consumed in GigaBytes by all the users in 24 hrs?

options.option_text: Statements i and iii are correct
Statements ii and iv are correct

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following is true about the term “stateful” in the client-server model?
question_texts: Which of the following is true about the term “stateful” in the client-server model?

options.option_text: The server responds to the client based on the previous state.
The server uses FTP protocol to respond to the client's request.
Network performance may reduce because of the large amount of data sentout repetitively.
Server is not required to maintain any state of client or session duringtransactions between client and server.
An employee can exist without having any salary slips
A salary slip can exist without belonging to any employee
An employee needs to have at least one salary slip
A salary slip must belong to one and only one employee

questions.question_text_1: Consider a client ‘C’ and a server ‘S’, separated by distance ‘D’ are connected by a fictitious medium in which the speed of light is ‘v’ m/sec. If ‘N’ is the number of consecutive requests that can made in a second by the client ‘C’ (i.e A new request can be made only after receiving the response from the previous request.), Which of the following changes would halve the number ‘N’?
question_texts: Consider a client ‘C’ and a server ‘S’, separated by distance ‘D’ are connected by a fictitious medium in which the speed of light is ‘v’ m/sec. If ‘N’ is the number of consecutive requests that can made in a second by the client ‘C’ (i.e A new request can be made only after receiving the response from the previous request.), Which of the following changes would halve the number ‘N’?

options.option_text: A change of medium where the speed of light is v/2 m/sec.
A change of medium where the speed of light is 2v m/sec.
Reduce the distance between C and S from D to D/2.
Increase the distance between C and S from D to 2D.

props.summary:
Here’s a structured summary of the **core topics, concepts, principles, and equations** essential for the **"Modern Application Development I"** exam, along with **Mermaid knowledge graphs** to visualize relationships. --- --- ## **1. Core Topics & Concepts** ### **A. Python & Templating Engines** #### **Key Concepts:** 1. **String Templating (`string.Template` vs `jinja2.Template`)** - `string.Template`: - Uses `$var` syntax. - `substitute()` raises `KeyError` if a placeholder is missing. - `safe_substitute()` ignores missing placeholders. - `jinja2.Template`: - Uses `{{ var }}` syntax. - Supports loops (`{% for %}`), conditionals (`{% if %}`), and macros. - `render()` substitutes variables from a dictionary. 2. **Command-Line Arguments (`sys.argv`)** - `sys.argv[0]` = Script name. - `sys.argv[1:]` = User-provided arguments. 3. **Python String Formatting** - f-strings, `.format()`, `%`-formatting. #### **Key Code Snippets:** ```python # string.Template from string import Template temp = Template("Hello, $name!") print(temp.substitute(name="World")) # "Hello, World!" # jinja2.Template from jinja2 import Template temp = Template("Hello, {{ name }}!") print(temp.render(name="World")) # "Hello, World!" # Command-line args import sys print(sys.argv[0]) # Script name print(sys.argv[1]) # First argument ``` --- ### **B. Flask (Web Framework)** #### **Key Concepts:** 1. **Routing (`@app.route`)** - Dynamic routes: ``, ``, ``. - HTTP methods: `GET`, `POST`, `PUT`, `DELETE`. 2. **Request Handling (`flask.request`)** - Query params: `request.args.get("key")`. - Form data: `request.form["key"]`. - JSON data: `request.json["key"]`. 3. **Jinja2 Templating in Flask** - Render templates: `render_template("file.html", data=data)`. - Template inheritance: `{% extends "base.html" %}`. - Macros, loops, conditionals. 4. **Flask-RESTful** - Define resources with `GET`, `POST`, etc. - Use `Api.add_resource(ResourceClass, "/endpoint")`. #### **Key Code Snippets:** ```python from flask import Flask, request, render_template app = Flask(__name__) @app.route("/user/") def greet(name): return f"Hello, {name}!" @app.route("/data", methods=["POST"]) def handle_data(): data = request.json return {"received": data} if __name__ == "__main__": app.run(debug=True) ``` --- ### **C. Frontend Basics** #### **Key Concepts:** 1. **HTML & CSS** - Semantic HTML (`
`, `
`, `
`). - CSS specificity: `!important` > inline > ID > class > element. - Box model: `margin`, `border`, `padding`, `content`. 2. **Frontend Frameworks** - **React.js**: Component-based, virtual DOM. - **Vue.js**: Reactive data binding, single-file components. - **Angular**: TypeScript-based, two-way data binding. - **Node.js**: Backend runtime (not frontend). 3. **Navigation Between Pages** - `Link` (correct). - `Link` (incorrect). --- ### **D. Databases & SQLAlchemy** #### **Key Concepts:** 1. **Database Indexes** - Can be created on **multiple columns**. - Can be created on **columns with duplicates**. - Improves `SELECT` query performance. 2. **Relationships in SQLAlchemy** - **One-to-Many**: - Foreign key in the "many" table. - `relationship("Child", back_populates="parent")`. - **One-to-One**: - Foreign key + `unique=True`. - **Many-to-Many**: - Association table with foreign keys to both tables. 3. **ER Diagrams** - **One-to-Many**: One `Book` → Many `Sections`. - **One-to-One**: One `Author` → One `Book` (`unique=True`). #### **Key Code Snippets:** ```python # One-to-Many (Book → Sections) class Book(Base): __tablename__ = "books" id = Column(Integer, primary_key=True) sections = relationship("Section", back_populates="book") class Section(Base): __tablename__ = "sections" id = Column(Integer, primary_key=True) book_id = Column(Integer, ForeignKey("books.id")) book = relationship("Book", back_populates="sections") ``` --- ### **E. Testing (Pytest)** #### **Key Concepts:** 1. **Pytest Basics** - Test files: `test_*.py` or `*_test.py`. - Test functions: `def test_*()`. - Assertions: `assert condition`. 2. **Fixtures (`@pytest.fixture`)** - Reusable setup/teardown logic. 3. **Markers (`@pytest.mark.*`)** - Run specific tests: `pytest -m marker_name`. 4. **Flask Testing** - `app.test_request_context()`: Simulate HTTP requests. - `url_for()`: Generate URLs for routes. #### **Key Code Snippets:** ```python # pytest example import pytest @pytest.mark.slow def test_add(): assert 1 + 1 == 2 # Flask test def test_home_route(): with app.test_request_context(): assert url_for("home") == "/" ``` --- ### **F. Git & Version Control** #### **Key Concepts:** 1. **Default Branch** - `main` (modern repos) or `master` (older repos). 2. **Basic Commands** - `git init`, `git add`, `git commit`, `git push`. --- ### **G. Networking & Performance** #### **Key Concepts:** 1. **Bandwidth & Data Transfer** - **Bandwidth (Mbps)** × **Time (seconds)** = **Data (Megabits)**. - Convert to **Gigabytes**: `(Megabits / 8) / 1024`. 2. **Latency & Speed of Light** - Time for data to travel: `distance / speed`. - Halving speed or doubling distance **doubles latency**. #### **Key Equation:** \[ \text{Data (GB)} = \frac{\text{Bandwidth (Mbps)} \times \text{Time (s)}}{8 \times 1024} \] --- ### **H. Cloud Computing (SaaS, PaaS, IaaS)** | Type | Example | Description | |------------|-----------------------|--------------------------------------| | **SaaS** | Office 365, Gmail | Software as a service. | | **PaaS** | Replit, Heroku | Platform for app development. | | **IaaS** | AWS, Azure | Infrastructure (VMs, storage). | --- ### **I. OpenAPI & API Documentation** - **`paths`**: Contains all API endpoints. - **`schema`**: Defines data models. - **`info`**: Metadata (title, version). - **`responses`**: HTTP response codes. --- ### **J. Testing Types** | Type | Description | |--------------------------|-----------------------------------------------------------------------------| | **Regression Testing** | Ensures new changes don’t break existing functionality. | | **User Acceptance Testing** | Validates software with real users (e.g., beta testing). | | **White Box Testing** | Tests internal logic (code coverage). | | **System Testing** | End-to-end testing of the full system. | | **Automation Testing** | Uses tools (Selenium) to simulate user interactions. | --- --- ## **2. Mermaid Knowledge Graphs** ### **Graph 1: Python Templating & Flask** ```mermaid graph TD A[Python Templating] --> B[string.Template] A --> C[jinja2.Template] B --> D[$var Syntax] B --> E[substitute/ safe_substitute] C --> F[{{ var }} Syntax] C --> G[Loops & Conditionals] C --> H[Flask Integration] I[Flask] --> J[Routing] I --> K[Request Handling] I --> L[Jinja2 Templating] I --> M[Flask-RESTful] J --> N[Dynamic Routes] K --> O[Query Params] K --> P[JSON Data] ``` ### **Graph 2: Databases & SQLAlchemy** ```mermaid graph TD A[Databases] --> B[SQLAlchemy] B --> C[Models] B --> D[Relationships] D --> E[One-to-Many] D --> F[One-to-One] D --> G[Many-to-Many] E --> H[Foreign Key in 'Many' Table] F --> I[Foreign Key + unique=True] G --> J[Association Table] K[ER Diagrams] --> L[Entities] K --> M[Relationships] M --> N[One-to-Many] M --> O[One-to-One] ``` ### **Graph 3: Frontend & Testing** ```mermaid graph TD A[Frontend] --> B[HTML/CSS] A --> C[Frameworks] C --> D[React.js] C --> E[Vue.js] C --> F[Angular] B --> G[Semantic HTML] B --> H[CSS Specificity] I[Testing] --> J[Pytest] I --> K[Flask Testing] I --> L[Testing Types] J --> M[Fixtures] J --> N[Markers] K --> O[test_request_context] L --> P[Regression] L --> Q[User Acceptance] L --> R[White Box] ``` ### **Graph 4: Networking & Cloud** ```mermaid graph TD A[Networking] --> B[Bandwidth] A --> C[Latency] B --> D[Data Transfer Calculation] C --> E[Speed of Light] C --> F[Distance Impact] G[Cloud Computing] --> H[SaaS] G --> I[PaaS] G --> J[IaaS] H --> K[Office 365] I --> L[Replit] J --> M[AWS] ``` --- --- ## **3. Key Equations (Math/Networking)** 1. **Data Transfer (GB):** \[ \text{Data (GB)} = \frac{\text{Bandwidth (Mbps)} \times \text{Time (s)}}{8 \times 1024} \] - Example: `10 Mbps × 4 hours × 3600 s/hour = 144,000 Mb`. Convert to GB: `144,000 / 8 / 1024 ≈ 17.58 GB`. 2. **Latency (Time for Data Travel):** \[ \text{Latency (s)} = \frac{\text{Distance (m)}}{\text{Speed (m/s)}} \] - If speed halves or distance doubles, latency **doubles**. 3. **Disk RPM Calculation:** \[ \text{RPM} = \frac{\text{Read Speed (bits/s)}}{\text{Bits per Revolution}} \times 60 \] - Example: `42,000 bits/s ÷ 600 bits/rev × 60 = 4,200 RPM`. --- --- ## **4. Exam Tips** 1. **Flask Routes:** - `/home/` matches `/home/abc` but not `/home/abc/def`. - `/home/` matches `/home/abc/def`. 2. **Jinja2 vs `string.Template`:** - Jinja2 supports logic (`{% if %}`), while `string.Template` does not. 3. **SQLAlchemy Relationships:** - One-to-Many: Foreign key in the "many" table. - One-to-One: Foreign key + `unique=True`. 4. **Pytest:** - Only functions named `test_*` are run. - `-k` filters tests by name, `-m` by markers. 5. **Git:** - Default branch is `main` (new repos) or `master` (old repos). 6. **Networking:** - Bandwidth × Time = Data. - Latency ∝ Distance / Speed. 7. **Frontend:** - `` is correct; `` is wrong. 8. **Cloud:** - SaaS (Software), PaaS (Platform), IaaS (Infrastructure).
